newsitem.title: USA: Fed should tighten if world dlr demand fell - Jordan.
newsitem.headline: Fed should tighten if world dlr demand fell - Jordan.

text.p: The Federal Reserve would need to tighten credit if there was a sudden loss of confidence in the dollar overseas and foreign demand for the currency fell, Cleveland Federal Reserve President Jerry Jordan said on Sunday.
"It would be necessary for us to contract or at least to severely limit the growth of our domestic central bank money," he told a meeting of the Association of Private Enterprise Education.

Jordan noted that the Fed expanded the growth of U.S. money after foreign demand for the American currency climbed following the collapse of the Soviet Union. Nearly two-thirds of U.S. currency is now held outside the United States.

But if that demand dried up -- either because of a loss of confidence in the dollar as a standard of value, or increased confidence by foreigners in their own domestic currencies -- the Fed would have to act to limit money supply, he said.
